thread.title: Theresa May's EU 'paranoia' will cost North East jobs, claims Labour
thread.title_full: Theresa May's EU 'paranoia' will cost North East jobs, claims Labour

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Theresa May's EU 'paranoia' will cost North East jobs, claims Labour
text:
News Theresa May's EU 'paranoia' will cost North East jobs, claims Labour Labour hits out after Conservative leader claims the EU is trying to fix the result of the general election Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Theresa May talks about nurses using Food Banks Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
Theresa May’s claim that the EU is trying to interfere in the general election has been condemned as “paranoia” by a Labour candidate. 
But the Conservative leader’s claims could have a damaging impact on North East jobs by making it harder to get a good Brexit deal for Britain, it was claimed. 
Catherine McKinnell , Labour’s candidate in Newcastle North, said she was concerned that Mrs May’s comments risk “totally souring our relations” with the EU. 
It follows the Prime Minister’s statement on Wednesday in which she accused Brussels and EU leaders of trying to affect the result of the June 8 general election, and said they wanted to ensure the UK failed to prosper after Brexit. 
Mrs May was responding to leaked reports of a meeting with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, which said the talks had gone badly. 
German leader Angela Merkel then said in a speech that “some in Britain still have illusions” about the Brexit process, in an apparent reference to the meeting. Prime Minister Theresa May makes a statement in Downing Street, London, after visiting Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace to mark the dissolution of Parliament for the General Election (Photo: PA) 
And it emerged that the EU was asking the UK to pay 100 billion Euros as it exited the EU , based on its share of EU liabilities and contributions the UK owes. 
All this prompted a remarkable statement from Mrs May, who said: “Britain’s negotiating position in Europe has been misrepresented in the continental press. The European Commission’s negotiating stance has hardened. 
“Threats against Britain have been issued by European politicians and officials. 
“All of these acts have been deliberately timed to affect the result of the General Election that will take place on June 8.” 
Ms McKinnell said the Prime Minister was attempting to appear tough, but the result would be damage to the North East’s economy. 
She said: “The bunker mentality and level of paranoia now being displayed by Theresa May is really quite disturbing and it’s actually like listening to Donald Trump. 
“We need to secure the best possible deal for Britain, and yet she risks totally souring our relations with Europe before the negotiations have even properly begun. 
“This has enormous consequences for the North East economy and local jobs, given so many of our region’s firm trade with Europe. It’s really shocking that she is willing to put that at risk, for the sake of appearing tough at this election.” Catherine McKinnell spoke out after new statistics from Australia show smoking is at an all time low 
A spokesman for Mr Juncker dismissed the Prime Minister’s claims, saying his office was “too busy” to meddle in the election. 
The president of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani, also insisted there was no attempt to influence the vote, Speaking at a Brussels press conference, Mr Tajani said: “We are not seeking to influence the result in the UK.” Read More Newcastle Labour candidate sparks backlash after controversial tweet about Prince Philip 
Mrs May’s comments follow claims that Russia interfered in last year’s US presidential elections to support Donald Trump. 
Leaving the EU will not be quick or painless for Britain, the European Commission’s chief negotiator has warned. 
Michel Barnier refused to be drawn on reports the Commission plans to hand Theresa May a bill of 100 billion euro (£84.5 billion), but said there must be a “settling of accounts”. 
But Brexit Secretary David Davis insisted “we will not be paying 100 billion”. 
He said, if Brussels failed to reach a deal acceptable to Britain, the UK would pay nothing. Like us on Facebook
